Sadly, there's nothing particularly scientific in this video. When you look at the references underpinning these claims, the studies either outright refute what the person on-screen is claiming, the methodology of the study is questionable, more recent studies have debunked what the study has mentioned, or the data are insufficient to show what is being claimed.

This is the problem with the whole "some studies have shown. . " or "scientists say. . ." line of reasoning. While the claim may not be "false," it is "wrong," if the methodology is poor or there is "newer" science which shows the opposite to be true.

What I find interesting is the huge desire the public has to want racism to be real. For the most part - any claim of racism is believed without question - no matter how illogical the claim is. It seems to be that as time marches forward - the demand for racism gets higher and the supply gets lower - the less racism there is - the more you hear about racism.

<del>PLEASE READ</del> I used to be racist, I was raised by racists and my reasonings may be too simple for you to believe but if you're watching the video because you are interested in this stuff then take a second to consider what I'm about to say because it is all true. As I stated in the beginning I was a racist, full of hate and anger towards people of different color. I was a completely different type of my own being, to put it lightly, a monster in the making. Although I never physically harmed anyone "thank God", my mindset at a time was to the point where I wouldn't care if I did, it's just that The right opportunity never presented itself. I am 38 years old let's go back almost 7 years ago. I got a job at a casino and basically fell in love the moment I met a girl, I mean I fell hard and still falling everyday lol. Anyways, getting to know her over a couple weeks after already being in love she had recently told me she had a child, and that didn't bother me. One day we were having a conversation at work and she tells me that her son is racially mixed " I'm pretty sure she was afraid to tell me at first because I told her about my racist family" So needless to say I got very confused in my mind and in my heart.. but I asked myself what was so different about this woman that I had already fallen in love with? Was I going to convince myself and tell myself that the fact her son was mixed that I couldn't love her anymore??? the first time I met her son was when she came to get me and I believe we were going to get something to eat. Neiko was in his car seat, tiny adorable little thing ❤️ lol. I felt very uncomfortable and still very confused about what to do with this situation already loving her and not wanting to hurt her,.. so I "played along" so to speak. So a couple weeks go by and we go to the park to play at the jungle gym, we are playing and I remember his tiny little feet and legs going over the ladder from one part of the jungle gym to another, I'm guiding him till he gets Midway through the chain fence and asks me for a kiss. To be honest I was reluctant, I was raised a completely different way, in my mind I was doing something wrong but I chose to listen to my heart and I leaned in and he gave me a kiss on the cheek. The putrid stone that was encasing my heart completely shattered and ever since then I have been a completely different person. The hatred I had in me was such a waste of energy.. anger that was bottled up for no reason, it was all gone. I instantly felt so much better mentally I know this sounds like a made-up fairy tale but it's true, love saved me. Think of racism as a small fire burning in your heart, your first racial thoughts are the kindling, left alone that fire will burn out in time leaving the soil rich in nutrients for new and beautiful things to grow. But the more racial thoughts you have that's just another stick thrown on the fire, Before you know it the fire gets so big you cannot put it out and it destroys  everything. From where it started, and continues to destroy everything around it. Racism needs to be studied more now than ever we have studied psychopaths, serial killers, suicidal people, and all of the outcomes usually turn to medicine to help one's cope with either being crazy, extremely angry and or depressed. People aren't just born suicidal or born being a serial killer and what not..so it's not that you're born racist, it's seems to be linked to some type of traumatic episode that happened, or as in my case the way you are raised.. not to say that they can actually create a magic pill to get rid of racism but maybe something that can tone it down and help one see the lighter side of things because not everybody is as lucky as to have the situation I did. But being someone who can relate to the damage this mentally does was incredible, I would be just fine and then just by merely seeing someone of a different color, all of these emotions would mix up inside of my mind and completely ruin anything good that was inside of me. It would start with anger and then just run itself into a snowball effect of all of these other things that I would blame on others even though they had absolutely nothing to do with me.. it was crazy and it could really mess somebody up. Maybe this was all wishful thinking but I really hope that someday others can get this putrid darkness out of their souls and learn to really live and love. A true story:
I have a looong history as a coach....mostly inner city and mixed race blue collar areas, but some predominantly white as well. HS level mostly, but also youth leagues. I love hanging with the kids. Great times.
Several years ago, I coached youth (12-13 yr old) baseball in a white neighborhood. We had a very good team and we had 2 black kids on the team. One of them was a tremendous player. He was smallish but hit like a demon. I batted him 3rd of course....one of our best hitters. Great kid too. Always laughing and hanging with the other kids. He had one flaw tho. When he'd hit a ball a long way, he'd miss touching a base causing him to be called "out". He'd get so excited and try running so fast that he'd miss bases....A LOT !!
To take some pressure off him and try to relax him on the bases a bit, I dropped him in the batting order to 6th one game. There was a very specific reason for doing this.....and my other coaches agreed.
After that first game, his father confronted me on the field and LOUDLY (and publicly) called me a racist for doing this. I should have walked away, but I asked him "Did I suddenly TODAY become a racist ? He hit 3rd for 6 games and you didn't have an issue with me then . Why am I suddenly a racist ?"

He just turned and walked away waving his arms and repeating...."racist coaches". This is a common tactic. Walk away from logic.

I grew up in a country where systemic racism is literally enshrined in the country's constitution. There are some truths in this video, but most of it is a gross oversimplification of the issue and don't take into consideration multiple factors, including causality (as in assuming that some things are a cause of racism, than other external factors), and some studies cited in this video don't exactly work in the way this video describes, don't mention some important factors related to them and it looks like they're cherry picked, which ends up not showing the whole picture (not to mention that the studies themselves could face some statistical failures that are outside of researchers control, such as simple bad luck).

For example - let's look at the "resume names" research. First of all, let's look at weaknesses and potential confounds the researchers themselves mention:
"First, our outcome measure is crude [...]. Our procedure, simply measures callbacks for interviews [...]. However, we are not able to translate our results into gaps in hiring rates or earnings

"Another weakness is that the resumes do not directly report race but instead suggest race through personal names. This leads to various sources of concern. First, while the names are chosen to make race salient, some employers may simply not notice the names or not recognize their racial content [...]. Relatedly, because we are not assigning race but only race-specific name, our results are not representative of the average African American (who may not have such a racially distinct name)."

"Finally, and this is an issue pervasive in both our study and the pair-matching audit studies, newspaper ads represent only one channel for job search. As is well known from the existing literature, social networks are a common means through which people find jobs and one that clearly cannot be studied here. This omission would affect our results if African Americans use social networks more or if less discriminating employers rely more on networks." (This study is from 2003, so "social network" as we commonly understand it now is a bit different than it was back then, 15 years ago)

_"While these names clearly signal race, perhaps they also signal some other personal characteristics. More specifically, one might be concerned that employers are inferring social background
from the personal name. When employers read a name like “Tyrone” or “Latoya,” they may assume that the person comes from a disadvantaged background. In the extreme form of this social background interpretation, employers do not care at all about race but are discriminating only against the social background conveyed by the names we have chosen"_

"Consistent with a social background interpretation, the African American names we have chosen fall below the African American average. For African American male names, however, the gap between the experimental names and the population average is negligible. For White names, both the male and female names are above the population average."

"Names might also influence our results through familiarity. It might be that these African American names simply appear odd to human resource managers and that any odd name faces discrimination."

"Perhaps what appears as discrimination is actually the result of reverse discrimination. If qualified African Americans are thought to be in high demand, then employers with average quality jobs might feel that an equally talented African American would never accept an offer from them and thereby never call her or him in for an interview. Such an argument might also explain why African Americans do not receive as strong of a return as Whites to better resumes, since higher qualification only strengthens this argument."

"These facts suggest that perhaps other models may do a better job at explaining our findings. One simple alternative model is lexicographic search by employers. Employers receive so many resumes that they may use quick heuristics in reading these resumes. One such heuristic could be to simply read no further when they see an African American name. Thus they may never see the skills of African American candidates and this could explain why these skills are not rewarded. This might also to some extent explain the uniformity of discrimination since the screening process (i.e. looking through a large set of resumes) may be quite similar across the variety of jobs we examine." (this is about the fact, that black sounding names with a higher quality resume do not have a much higher chance of getting a callback (9% increase) compared to a white sounding name (30% increase). This could be due to racial discrimination, but could also be due to the point mentioned further, about names implying social background)

*Now let's look at their findings: *
"Resumes with White names have a 10.08 percent chance of receiving a callback. Equivalent resumes with African American names have a 6.70 percent chance of being called back. This represents a difference in callback rates of 3.35 percentage points, or 50 percent, that can solely be attributed to the name manipulation." 10% White vs 7% Black resumes got a callback. Doesn't sound that impressive now, doesn't it?

Also, it's noteworthy to say, that no, resumes WERE NOT IDENTICAL, they were JUST ON A SIMILAR LEVEL. Also - the researchers sent up to 4 resumes in respons to each ad (two higher quality and two lower quality ones).

"As Table 2 indicates, equal treatment occurs for about 87.5 percent of the help-wanted ads. As expected, the major source of equal treatment comes from the high fraction of ads for which no callbacks are recorded (82.5 percent of the ads). Whites are favored by nearly 9 percent of the employers, with a majority of these employers contacting exactly one White applicant. African Americans, on the other hand, are favored by only about 3.7 percent of employers."


See? It's not so simple as "50% more callbacks" now, is it? And yes, what the study finds is most likely accurate (or was, 15 years ago), it's only uncertain if the real reason is racial discrimination or is there any other factor (few of which the researchers themselves mentioned and I've cited them here). I could go into more detail, but It's an already loooong comment and I've spent way too much time on it (bit over half an hour xD), so let's leave it at that.

Alright, racism is no where near as prévalant as before. This video is garbage, i made a select few rules for myself that really make life easier. When i meet a new person i do not look at their face, i look them in the eye and shake their hand. The way they respond to the friendly gesture tells me a lot about their personality, i treat them with respect and see if they bounce it back. Ive grown up around plenty of different people and constantly moving kinda helps you learn about people. I will always respect someone when first meeting them no matter what i have heard, and see how they respond then i will start a conversation, keeping eye contact and watching their face for what they are thinking. I let them finish what they say before saying what i would like too. I am not political but i am polite. I don’t open with anything more than the weather. I do my best not to stereotype. And above all else when you greet someone, smile. It makes things easier. With that said, racism in my own opinion (yours may differ but that’s fine!) is ridiculous, we are not very different, where you were raised makes a difference, like maybe more used to cold or dry climates. The only way to “get over racism” is to get over ourselves first, realizing that we are all different even if we are the same “race” that differences make life interesting from the cut and dry mortar. Isn't 'biased' that at the beginning of the video when they talked about the "resume study" , they attributed it to racism BUT when they mentioned the "citation study" at the end, they concluded it was basically an anti-racism strategy?

This isn't a scientific video, there are a lot of assumptions and misinformation. For example, when they talked about the "resume study" (Bertrand & Mullainathan, 2004) they claim the "resumes were identical" however this isn't true, the authors of the study classify the resumes in an arbitrary fashion and there was no actually indication that the resumes were kept identical. Later in this video they claim that black names received 50% less callbacks, but that again, isn't true, looking at the data of the study, it states that white names received 7.8% callbacks out of 62 attempts (5 calls), meanwhile, black names received 6.6% callbacks out of 62 attempts (4 calls), so the difference is... ONE call. But we all know that if you have a certain statistic framework, you can make all type of conclusions, and this is what this study did. Oh, and it's very interesting that this video didn't mention the difference between names within the same race, in which in this study it showed there was as large as most of the between-race differences.

It's a shame how deceptive AsapScience is becoming.

Ok, I'm Black and Japanese, but I thought this video was completely contradicting the point to acknowledge racism. While I do believe we live in a partly racist society I strongly disagree with this video in many ways, but at the same time we do share some views. I will acknowledge all MAIN points in this video from start to finish, and while you may have a different opinion than me, it is very important to keep an open mind, or you will not understand where I come from.

The first main point starts off with the research on the “Resumes”. The video states “Black sounding names” receive 50% fewer callbacks, now I’m just a 15 year old kid writing this so i'm not going to go all out like I could, but their are so many variables that can change which could lead to these outcomes, don’t believe me, well let me explain. Many jobs have different interview rates, which you can see on a post made by “Talent Works”, so unless the “1300 Fake Resumes” were sent to the same job you must account for this. Now let's talk about timing, if you ever worked a night shift at a fast food restaurant you’re probably not doing your best, this apply for all jobs, including employers. And if there is one thing I learned in my sociology class it’s that humans are unpredictable so we must not give the benefit of the doubt to 1300 resumes in proving a racist society in the world of the jobs.

I’m going to keep this section short and simple as it was in the video, “Classism”. While I do believe we have a unfair punishment act in prison and school. I can also see where other people may come from. For example a black male vs. a white male in 1st degree murder. While studies show, at least what this video suggest, black males get a longer prison time then white, we must account for, just because they did the same crime does not mean it was the same circumstances, what I mean by this is a person getting shot vs. a person getting brutally stabbed, both are murder but one is much worse. So I can see were different views can come out of this.

The next subject I will touch is how racism affects health. This video states and I literally quote, Racism = Health Disparities. I can see how this may be true but again I will talk about how I see it. Like I said this video shows how racism can create health risk, yet in my opinion (no study) I can argue racism enhances health risk already there. So let's not exaggerate the truth guys.

Love how people are freaking out at the thought of anyone challenging the veracity of this video just because it is supposed to be scientific. First, science is all about about the comparison of multiple findings and, as such, critique as the very core of science. Second, science is often about the details as opposed to the conclusions, which was the only aspect of these studies that was shown. This is primarily because the methodology of how the data is acquired is the presentation of such data is the limiting factor in what a researcher can conclude about it. Third, science is all about the consensus of data pulled from multiple studies so there could be plenty of other sociological studies challenging the ones you see in this video and they could very well offer more robust methodology/data/conclusions. The video didn't go over anything except the conclusions of the studies, not even the limitations of the studies, and tried to pass these conclusions as fact when it may very well not the case. For example, the data of different names on resumes being indicative of racism isn't clear cut and there are other studies that fail to replicate the results shown here or give alternative rationales as to why first names, as opposed to last names, create this effect. This would, of course, seem racist to anyone who hasn't been exposed to any other studies or isn't prone to critical thinking, which is why videos like these are rather disappointing coming from a channel that purports to be scientific. Let's be honest and admit virtually none of us went through the trouble of even reading the abstract in these studies, much less the methodology, so stop saying that these studies can't be debunked, because all you're showing is your confirmation bias as opposed to any real scientific intellect. In fact, blindly believing this video is about as unscientific as it gets.

I believe racism is a biproduct of poverty and lack of education. It is not something society is creating or forcing, but a result from communities that are closed and unaware, which is inevitable when those people don't have access to or contact with the outside world. Since the 90s, racism has fallen drastically as the internet was created and economic migrants travel the world.

Right now, racism is simply when people aren't used to seeing something or someone unfamiliar. It is an issue that is slowly being resolved when the world becomes more connected. So in theory, this video is completely unnecessary. Why? Because it is not only spreading awareness of something that is blatantly obvious, but it also makes "minorities" to feel more victimised than they really are. There's a lot of cherry picking in this video, and it's wrong.

(1) Name Bias Study : The actual study is being misrepresented as both blacks and whites didn't have the same resume. In fact, the paper even admits to changing it somethings. The call-back difference was small, but due to the statistical way it was done, they claimed a 20% difference. Regardless, Carriol (2015) re-looked at the study and found that the way the resume is presented has a bigger impact than race.

(2) Same crime, Same time : Not really. Most studies only look at past criminal record and age, but controlling for more variables makes the gap go away. Beaver (2015) found that controlling for past criminal record and IQ made the gap completely go away, and Starr and Rahavi (2012) found that controlling for multiple variables made the gap shrink, but the disparity left was a result of charging differences.

(3) The next few examples were just correlation = causation; the heart rate study is just dumb. If you accuse someone of racial bias then of course their heart rate will increase. I doubt some of these (like the contact theory) have been replicated outside of controlled environments.

Here I'll tell you why racism exists... Unlike this video. Racism is just one of many forms of bias against a specific group of people, ie because of the colour of their skin. Racism in of itself is therefore unjustified, and widely considered foolish. The problem is that the word racism is often used incorrectly to define cultural bias, and religious bias. Religious and cultural bias is (in a Nutt shell) judging someone for their beliefs. Many cultures and religions have a predominant race, therefore racism can exist by assuming someone's cultural or religious beliefs based on their skin colour. More often than not someone who disagrees with religious or cultural beliefs are at best considered intolerant, and at worst labeled as racist. This is the problem, because cultural and religious bias' can be justified. There are very evident differences in certain belief systems that do not, and cannot, coexist. There is nothing wrong with you disliking another cultures way of life specifically if it threatens your own. These days however, in an age of hyper self segregation, there is a movement pushing a fascist form of anti-free speech which seeks to label white people who dislike anything about any other minority culture or religion as racist/ bigots. It's gotten so insane that videos like this one exist, masquerading as progressive all the while being racist towards white people by insinuating that most racism is performed by whites. WHAT!!! How could I say that?? Isn't that horrible??? Yes, IMHO, all intolerance is - whether it be racial or political or ...
What I am referring to as being inherently human is the more general behavior of Tribalism.
Studies I have seen recently posit that as we were developing, humans found they could benefit by banding together in a mutually supported group and siding faithfully with their group against all others. This tribalism seems to have given our ancestors a competitive advantage.
The good thing is that WE CAN USE OUR BRAINS to make a choice to NOT be tribal - whether that is to side with our race, or religion, or our politics, we CAN choose to think look and listen BEFORE we act and speak. IMHO, the solution is not as much education as it is choosing to build relationships (valuing and spending time) with other people from our out-group and growing their (and our) tribe until it encompasses all people.

I question the study of possible heart attack treatment. Even though a heart attack is a heart attack. The underlying causes does differ between different groups of people that it is significantly measurable. Diet's, daily habits, genes, etc. So saying they were less likely to prescribe a drug doesn't mean anything. Because if you eat crap food all day with no exercise then certain medications will not help and could possibly make things worse. For the people ranting on about how "correlation does not equal causation": well, that's true, and you can't outright claim one variable causes the other with that information alone.  However, we scientists often provide the best supporting evidence for causation through experimental studies, and you can't ethically and practically do that with these variables.  To my knowledge, you couldn't assign people randomly to different treatment groups (i.e., a group which experiences no racist behaviors, a group with minimal racist experiences, one with more such experiences, and so on) and monitor them for physical and mental health changes over the course of years.  If you could, that would probably provide decent support of causation, based on the results, but we can't do that kind of study.  So the best we can do is see if there is a relationship between those variables (i.e., as one goes up/down, so does the other) based on the data available or ethically/practically obtainable.  There may be other variables that account for those correlations (e.g., genetic traits, neurological changes, early life experiences, or hell, even their astrological signs for shits and giggles), but it's likely that the researchers have taken a good amount of those into account when looking at the relationships.  So, congratulations, you remembered a thing that a teacher once stressed to you in a class you probably couldn't care less about now.  The reality of human behavioral research means that a lot of what we're interested in learning can't be supported by experimental evidence (as a doctoral student I had to learn that sad reality and lost a little of the passion I originally had for research).  As such, the best we're often left with is seeing which things statistically relate to each other and making sense of those relationships with the knowledge we already have.  A responsible scientist also wouldn't outright claim that they have "proved" that one thing "causes" the other, but state that they found this statistically relevant relationship and there is a good chance that if you alter one variable you might see changes to the other.  The scientist might also offer up that it is entirely plausible that some heretofore unconsidered variable could be responsible for this relationship, and further investigation would be helpful.  In the end, we have evidence that there is something going on here, and it is rather irresponsible for you to toss out the whole idea that anything is happening simply because you can recite a phrase.

Before I start, I do think racism exists, but it's not as systemic as some people would like to believe, it's more like the occasional person having prejudices towards someone else, rather than an entire demographic having biases.

Having said this I want to discuss the first 4 studies in the description (because analyzing all of them requires way too much time and I can't be bothered)

1) The study is focused on two cities (Boston and Chicago) and the resumes are just in 4 job categories; while the results are interesting, that's a bit too thin to derive a clear conclusion. Also the fact that it's from 2003 doesn't help, in fact 15 years is a lot of time for the job market and political climate to evolve, so its results might not be relevant today.
This doesn't mean the study is useless, it would be great to attract fund for a bigger study (Nationwide and that encompasses a large amount of jobs), as it might indicate a trend that is worth studying on, but by itself it can't be used as an effective argument for systemic racism.

2) What strikes me from this study is that black women have no problem concerning income when compared with black men. I find it extremely difficult to believe this is due to systemic racism, because it doesn't make sense that males experience it, while females don't.
A factor, that is also discussed in the article, is that most black families are composed of single mothers, and we know very well the effect that this kind of situation has on children, females might not feel it as much because their mother might empathize, and therefore have more care) more with them than boys, also the lack of role models is crucial.
It's interesting to note that similar trends have been found for native Americans boys, and in fact they have similar percentages of single parent kids to blacks (54% vs 66%).
(See https://datacenter.kidscount.org/data/tables/107-children-in-single-parent-families-by#detailed/1/any/false/870,573,869,36,868,867,133,38,35,18/10,11,9,12,1,185,13/432,431)

3) see 2), the lack of role models when growing up leads to aberrant behavior, that can explain why teachers tend to escalate reactions towards black students. Does this mean that there aren't biases? Of course not, but we have to apply Occam's razor: what's more likely, that black kids get harser punishments because teachers are overwhelmingly biased against them (which is an assumption), or that black kids grow up unstable because of lack of role models (which is backed up by statistical data)?

4) I've read the paper but I can't understand how they are drawing their conclusions, for the first study at least: they basically assigned a score for each age group and each race, but they don't specify how they calculated said scores, so it's impossible for someone else to determine whether or not differences in score are significant (which don't seem to be that bigger anyway).
For what concerns the second study (the one with the police officers) it could be explained by the simple reason that black communities are responsible for a disproportionate amount of crime, so they may be acting based on their experience. Though possibilities of actual discrimination can't be excluded, since the police in the United States has a lot of anecdotal evidence about being way to violent when it comes to blacks.

So these 4 don't really convince me that systemic racism exists. Maybe if you can point me towards other studies that might be more conclusive and/or convincing, then I will read them in full.

This video, while it made some very good points, was still rather one-sided in its arguments. There's actually a growing body of scientists who'd argue that, despite everyone's desire to believe that all people are created equal, the unpleasant reality is that races and ethnic groups are unequal in many significant ways. While it's true that every individual should be evaluated on his or her own merits and deserves the same respect as everyone else regardless of race, tens of thousands of years of natural selection seem to have made some races better on average than others when it comes to certain abilities. People of African descent, for example, are much more likely to suffer from lactose intolerance and diabetes than white people, but they have greater immunity to certain diseases like malaria. Black people are also more likely to excel at sports like competitive running, whereas white people are more adept at sports like weight-lifting and swimming. When it comes to intelligence, black people as a group tend to score much lower on IQ tests and other measures of academic aptitude such as the SATs, GREs, ACTs etc. (For evidence of this, see the following sources: https://www.ets.org/s/gre/pdf/gre_general_test_score_information_by_ethnicity_2009_2010.pdf and https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/9780815746096_chapter1.pdf) This so-called IQ gap persists is in spite of large scale efforts to boost black test scores through a variety of social and educational programs. Of course, there are many brilliant black people out there, but statistically brilliance is much rarer among those of African descent, at least as measured by standard metrics of intelligence.

Finally, blacks are statistically much likelier to act impulsively and commit crimes, particularly violent crimes, than their white or Asian counterparts. Wikipedia has this to say: "The rate at which crime is committed varies greatly between racial groups. While most homicides in the United States are intraracial—the perpetrator and victim are of the same race—the rates at which African Americans (blacks) both commit and are the victim of homicide is about six to eight times higher than that of white Americans. The incarceration rate of blacks is more than three times higher than their representation in the general population." Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_crime_in_the_United_States. African countries, or countries with large populations of African immigrants, also tend to exhibit much higher murder rates, as is evidenced in the following article: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_intentional_homicide_rate.

As long as these differences between races exist, there's always going to be racism, in part because such racism corresponds with large-scale behavior patterns. Unfortunately, it seems natural selection may itself be what some would call racist, in that it inevitably causes a species to adapt in different ways to different environments, and this in turn leads to sub-species with different abilities and disabilities.

(On a side note, it seems pretty obvious that scientific papers with authors of different ethnic backgrounds will have more citations for reasons other than those given in the video. There's no special synergy that occurs when people of different backgrounds work together, as this video implies; instead, they'll simply have more exposure and often more funding and resources than researchers who all come from the same university with similar backgrounds. It's for the same reason that musical artists from different genres who collaborate on a song will tend to have more listeners than musical artists who stay confined within the same genre.)

I think your argument about racial bias being created and not born is flawed. The evidence for bias being inherited is much weaker than the evidence for bias being born. If a person is born with "group mentality", similar to how that study put it, there is an innate part of the person's brain that causes them to want to separate themselves due to fear of the unknown, and if they were raised in a "non racist" (parents punished racist behavior and teachers taught about racism) lifestyle, however all their friends were white and their parents were white, they would still show signs of racial bias simply because they were raised by that group and affiliate themselves with that group. This happens in a very similar manner with white children who are around mostly black people. They associate themselves strongly there too.

I'm not saying the act of racism doesn't make it worse or can change people's opinions. I'm saying your evidence for racism being taught is slightly misleading. That evidence points more to people actually being born biased, in which mixed race parents and friends help weaken that group mentality.
